source.name: Creating Arrays
source.instructions: Rearrange the code to create an array of all the odd numbers between 0 and 30 (inclusive). Print the third item of the array when you are done. (Assume the code is part of the main() method.)
source.guidance: This code starts by creating an array of size 15 (30/2 = 15 odd numbers). Note that this is done with the code ```int[] oddNums = new int[15]```, being sure to specify the data type and size of the array. Then, the code uses a for loop and a counting variable ```x``` to fill each index of the array with the next successive odd number. (There are a lot of ways to do this part, but none of the other ways were included in the options here.) Finally, it prints out the third element, which is index 2 because array indices begin at 0.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT use a for loop to create an array with a range of odd numbers.

source.name: Editing Array Values
source.instructions:
Rearrange the following code so that the elements of the array ```my_array``` are the following numbers, in order: 

```
42
37
9
3
215
6
```

Assume the code is part of the main method. You must only initialize the array once.

Make sure to edit the indices of the array IN ASCENDING ORDER in order to pass the autograder.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT modify an array to certain requirements.

source.name: Creating ArrayLists
source.instructions:
Write a program that executes the following steps in order:
- Create an ArrayList of Integers called my_array_list.
- Add the numbers 93 and 321 to it in that order. 
- Print the second element in the list. 
- Then remove 321 from the list. 
- Add 73, 42, and 16. 
- Print the third element in the list.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT create and make modifications to an ArrayList.

source.name: Birthday ArrayList
source.instructions: Rearrange the below code so that the characters in the ArrayList charAL spell out ```HAPPY BIRTHDAY```. Then, print out the letter D using the ArrayList .get() method. (Assume the code is part of the main() method and all requisite libraries are imported.)
source.initial:
ArrayList<Character> charAL = new ArrayList<>();
for (char c : "HAPPY BIRTHDAY".toCharArray()) charAL.add(c);
System.out.println(charAL.get(charAL.indexOf('D')));
ArrayList<> charAL = new ArrayList<>();                    #distractor
for (String c : "HAPPY BIRTHDAY") charAL.add(c);                    #distractor
System.out.println(charAL.get("D"));                    #distractor
char[] hbd = (char[])hbdString;            #distractor
String hbdString = "happy birthday!";         #distractor
System.out.println(charAL);                    #distractor
ArrayList<Character> charAL = hbdString.toArrayList();             #distractor
ArrayList<Character> charAL = "HAPPY BIRTHDAY".toArrayList();           #distractor
ArrayList<Character> charAL = new ArrayList<>("HAPPY BIRTHDAY");                    #distractor
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT make an ArrayList of the characters in Happy Birthday and then printing out a certain letter from the list.

source.name: Array Conversion
source.instructions:
Given a ```String[] args``` of any size in which each position is held by a random number, write a function ```arrayConverter()``` that will do the following:
- Create an int[] that stores each of these numbers multiplied by 3 (you'll have to convert them to ints first, of course). 
- Return the sixth element of this array.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT convert a String[] to an int[] and return a certain element.

source.name: Retrieving the Next Node
source.guidance: To find the next node connected to the current one, the function must return the `next` instance variable of the Node object. In Java, this is done by returning this.nextNode.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT utilize a Node class to retrieve the next node of a linked list.

source.name: Adding Elements to Linked Lists
source.initial:
NewNode.nextVal = ExistingNode.nextVal;
ExistingNode.nextVal = NewNode;
NewNode.nextVal = null;         #distractor
ExistingNode.nextVal =  null;         #distractor
NewNode = Node;         #distractor
ExistingNode = NewNode.nextVal;    #distractor
ExistingNode = NewNode; #distractor
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT insert elements into linked lists in Java

source.name: Removing Elements from Linked Lists
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT remove an element from a linked list in Java

source.name: Basic to arrays
source.instructions: An array is a collection of items stored at ______ memory locations.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT understand array memory location

source.name: Array memory storing
source.instructions: What kind of variable will arrays store?
source.guidance: A variable of the same type will is are variables that are either whole numbers, text, or decimals.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT understand the between types of variables

source.name: Array index
source.instructions: Based on what you please fill in the blank.
source.text: In most programming language an array index will start at the #<<<0>>>.
source.guidance: The first element of most programming languages will start at 0. If you are putting 10 elements in the array then the last element will have a location 9.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT understand the location of data in an array.

text: In most programming language an array index will start at the #

source.name: Use of arrays
source.instructions: Why do we need arrays? (select all that apply)

answers.answer: Store a numbered collection of similar data
Iteration through contiguous elements is fast
Adding and removing elements from the end of the array is also fast
for a better understanding of decision making from the CPU.

source.learningObjectives: SWBAT remember what are the uses of an array

source.name: Adding to Hash Tables
source.instructions:
Rearrange the following code blocks to do the following:
- Initialize a HashTable ```student_nums``` of students' names and ID numbers. 
- Then add 3 students (Jane, John, and Sarah).
**IMPORTANT:** First add Jane, then add John, and then add Sarah.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify the right ways to add items to a hash table.

source.name: Using Java HashTables
source.instructions: Given a HashTable that maps students to their favorite numbers, print out Jane's favorite number. If Jane is not in the list of students, ensure that your program prints ```null```.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT call .get() on a HashTable.

source.name: Push & Pop
source.instructions:
You are given a Stack, my_stack, that looks like this:

```
3
2
1
```

(It would print out like ```[1, 2, 3]```.)

Rearrange the following blocks of code so that the stack looks like this:

```
3
4
5
6
2
1
```
(It should print out like ```[1, 2, 6, 5, 4, 3]```.)
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT call .push() and .pop() on a stack.

source.name: Searching in Stacks
source.instructions: Which of the following is the correct way to get the position of an item ```a``` in the stack ```stack1```?
source.guidance:
```
System.out.println(stack1.search(a));
```
The following answer correctly calls the ```.search()``` method on the stack with ```a``` as a parameter.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT recall how to search a stack.

source.name: Add & Remove
source.instructions:
You are given a Queue, my_queue, that looks like this:

```
3
2
1
```

(It would print out like ```[1, 2, 3]```.)

Rearrange the following blocks of code so that the queue looks like this:

```
1
4
5
6
3
2
```
(It should print out like ```[2, 3, 6, 5, 4, 1]```.)
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT add and remove elements in a queue.

source.name: First Element
source.instructions: Which of the following will get the first element in a queue ```my_queue```, *and return null if the queue is empty*?
source.guidance:
```
System.out.println(my_queue.peek());
```
The correct method to return the first element or "head" of the queue, and return null in an empty queue, is ```.peek()```. ```.element()``` will also return the head of the queue, but it throws an exception if there are no elements in the queue.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT recall how to get the first element in a queue.

source.name: Creating a Stack
source.instructions: Fill in the following class DIYStack to create a fully functional stack. For this exercise, you must implement the methods yourself -- extending another class will result in code not passing the autograder. For the ```.pop()``` and ```.peek()``` methods, ensure that your code will return a ```null``` value if the stack is empty. Each method has more specific instructions written in a comment. For this implementation, you will need to store each element in a Node so that users can push either fully formed Nodes or other data types onto the stack. You are given the Node class, as well as more specific instructions in the two ```.push()``` methods.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT implement a Stack data structure

source.name: Creating a Node
source.instructions:
Write a program that defines a linked list node that holds a name. Your program should do the following:
- Define a `Node` class with instance variables `name` (a String) and `next` (another Node).
- Define a constructor that accepts the `name` and `next` parameters in that order, and assigns them to the instance variables.
- In the method ```nodeName()```, do the following:
   - Create a linked list of one node that holds the name "Maria".
   - Return the name of the node.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT create a node class in Java

source.name: Using Nodes to Make a Linked List
source.instructions:
Order the following code snippets to create a linked list with 5 nodes.

**Note:** The contract of the Node constructor is `new Node(T data, Node next)`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT use nodes to create a linked list

source.name: Creating a Linked List
source.instructions: Order the code snippets to create a linked list class with a constructor. The constructor should take in one node as the linked list's head node.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT create a linked list class in Java

source.name: Using the Node Class to Create a Linked List
source.instructions:
Given the following contract, fill in the blank to create a linked list of length 4.

```java
new Node(T data, Node next_node)
```
source.guidance: Each node's constructor should take in the previously created node to form the linked list.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT recognize nodes' dependency on other nodes

source.name: Determine whether parentheses are balanced using a stack
source.instructions:
When you write code in Codio, Codio will flag parentheses that are not balanced that will prevent your code from working. This an important functionality that many IDEs and compilers use.

Write a function called `paren_balanced()`
that takes in a string of parentheses and returns `True` if the parentheses are balanced, and `False` if they are not.

Note: the string will only consist of `(` and `)` characters.

Sample input and output:
* `()` -> `True`
* `(())` -> `True`
* `(())()(())` -> `True`
* empty string -> `True`
* `(` -> `False`
* `))` -> `False`

Use the stack class defined in the starter code in `balanced_paren.py` to solve this problem.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT leverage understanding of stacks to determine whether parentheses are balanced in a string

source.name: Types of Traversal
source.instructions: From the following list, select all the valid methods of tree traversal.
source.guidance: The five types of tree traversals are postorder, preorder, inorder, level order, and reverse level order.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT remember the types of tree traversals.

source.name: Preorder Traversal
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT understand the preorder method of tree traversal.

source.name: Postorder Traversal
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT understand the postorder method of tree traversal.

source.name: Inorder Traversal
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT understand the inorder method of tree traversal.

source.name: Creating a Queue
source.instructions:
Fill in the following class DIYQueue to create a fully functional stack. 

**Ensure that your code follows the below requirements:** 
- For this exercise, you must implement the methods yourself  extending another class will result in code not passing the autograder. 
- For the .dequeue() and .peek() methods, ensure that your code will return a `null` value if the queue is empty.
- For the .allNodesString() method, ensure that you **BOTH RETURN AND PRINT** a visual representation of the queue (i.e. a newline between each element such that the next element to be popped is on the "bottom").
- For this implementation, users must be able to queue either fully formed Nodes or values -- if a value is not input as a Node, encapsulate it in a Node before queueing it.

Each method has more specific instructions written in a comment.  You are given the Node class.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT create a queue class in Java
